properties.name: Angola-Cholera Outbreak
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Photo : P. Arevalo, MSF | Angola Cholera in Angola: Second Deadly Outbreak Following the latest outbreak, the international humanitarian medical organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has reopened its previous intervention.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Armenia-Basic Healthcare
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Alexander Glyadyelov Access To Healthcare As she nears her decrepit house we see that the 82 year old woman is limping badly. The MSF doctor explains to her that the risk of gangrene is high and that, unless she comes to the nearby clinic, she runs the risk of amputation.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Bangladesh-Refugees from Myanmar
properties.description: New Page 1 © Greg Constantine Near the city of Teknaf, 6,000 Rohingya refugees from the neighboring Myanmar (Burma) live in terrible conditions in a camp. Classified by the Bangladeshi government as illegal immigrants, the people were not supported till MSF began a small healthcare center. im  Why some volunteer for MSF proving the ter supply and sanitary conditions in the camp

properties.name: Benin-HIV/AIDS Care
properties.description: New Page 1 Video shown on preventing HIV/AIDS in community of Adohoun Shifting care to HIV-positive patients After years of helping patients living with a condition known as Buruli ulcer, MSF is now refocusing its activities in the country to assist the growing number of people affected by HIV/AIDS. In 2002, MSF started offering HIV/AIDS-related care in a health center in the town of Dogbo, Mono-Couffo Department.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Bolivia-Chagas disease
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Treating those with Chagas disease Chagas disease kills more than 50,000 people every year in Latin America. Bolivia is the hardest hit country. MSF is treating people with Chagas disease in Bolivia's O'Connor Province and in the slums of Sucre.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Burundi-Recovery from War
properties.description: MSF Country Summary MSF staff provide care to desperate Rwandan refugees gathered in the Songore transit camp in Burundi. Photo © MSF Treating civilians affected by warMSF works in many parts of Burundi, treating war wounded, caring for victims of sexual violence, responding to disease outbreaks and providing basic medical care.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Cambodia-Focus On HIV/AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo : Roger Job, MSF | Cambodia. Expanding care for those living with deadly diseases MSF's activities in Cambodia focus on treating people with the deadly diseases of HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. Though the country has been relatively stable politically since 1998, a long history of conflict and violence has left its mark on this southeast Asian country.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Cameroon-Fighting infectious diseases
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An MSF doctor conducts daily rounds in Cameroon. Photo © Juan Carlos Tomas Focusing on people with infectious diseases In Cameroon, MSF assists some of those living with either HIV/AIDS or Buruli ulcer. The number of people living with HIV/AIDS has increased sharply during the last decade. Today 11 percent of the population is HIV positive, approximately 937,000 people.    Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Central African Republic-Malaria & Sleeping Sickness
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Often, 100 to 200 people attend the mobile clinics, which are their only way to obtain medical care © Ton Koene Doctors Without Borders/ Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) began working in northwestern Central African Republic (CAR) in November 2005.  Among the population, word has spread about MSF teams performing mobile clinics in these deserted villages. The displaced people are then coming out of the forest to receive medical attention.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Chad-Refugees from Sudan
properties.description: MSF Country Summary A young girl is vaccinated in Forchana camp near the Sudanese border. Photo © Stephan Grosse Rueschkamp Caring for Darfur refugees and vaccinating thousands In November, a new wave of violence hit civilians in remote eastern Chad not far from its increasingly tense border with Sudan's Darfur region.MSF teams are assisting victims in Koloye and villages south of Goz Beida, and treating war wounded in Abéché.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Chechnya-Healthcare In Crisis
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Denis Lemasson / MSF MSF continues to distribute medicine and medical material to Grozny Maternity, which is the central maternity and referral hospital for all of Chechnya. In 2005, MSF provided drugs in support of 125,740 medical consultations in health structures in Shatoi, Sharoi and Itum Kale.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Colombia-Endemic Violence
properties.description: MSF Country Summary MSF provides essential medical services in various urban and rural areas of the country, using both fixed health posts and mobile clinics. Photo © Jesus Abad Colorado In an effort to alleviate some of the suffering, MSF provides essential medical services in various urban and rural areas of the country, using both fixed health posts and mobile clinics to reach people in desperate need of basic care.    Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Democratic Republic of Congo-Victims of Violence
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo © Francesco Zizola Despite efforts at disarmament and reintegration, principally by the United Nations, numerous rebel groups continue to wage war, rendering large swathes of the region inaccessible to aid workers and destroying lives with their often indiscriminate terror. Some of the victims are treated by an MSF team working in the Bon Marché Hospital in the provincial capital of Bunia.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Ecuador-HIV/AIDS Clinics
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo : MSF Pushing for more access to AIDS medicines More than half of Ecuador's inhabitants cannot obtain proper medical carea problem that has intensified with the spread of HIV/AIDS. In January 2004, MSF launched a project to improve care for people with HIV/AIDS in western Guayas province.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Ethiopia-TB & AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo : Petterik Wiggers, MSF | Bringing TB treatment to nomads Since January 2001, more than 2,500 Afar patients have been cared for in an MSF rural TB treatment center according to a regimen designed especially for nomadic people living with TB. Approximately 40 new patients are admitted each month.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Georgia-Fighting TB
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Simon Lourie     A patient sits in his room during his months-long treatment for tuberculosis. Wars with the secessionist republics of South Ossetia and Abkhazia and the dismantling of the Soviet Union have left Georgia close to economic and social collapse.  Tuberculosis (TB) is one of the area's leading causes of illness and death. MSF also suspects that many people with TB in this area suffer from harder-to-treat multidrug-resistant (MDR) strains of the disease.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Guatemala-HIV/AIDS Clinics
properties.description: MSF Country Summary A mother sits with her children during a medical consultation in Olopa, Chiquimula. Photo © Juan Carlos Tomasi Confronting a growing AIDS crisis While an estimated 13,500 people are in urgent need of treatment for AIDS, merely 3,900 Guatemalans receive it  almost half of them (1,900) treated by MSF in hospitals and clinics.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Guinea-Malaria & TB
properties.description: MSF Country Summary photo credit: Roger Job Improving malaria and TB care Current MSF activities in Guinea focus on treating people with malaria, TB and HIV/AIDS, though MSF continues to respond to emergencies as necessary.  Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Haiti-Urban Violence
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An MSF surgical team during a laparatomy at St Joseph Hospital. Photo © Guillaume le Duc/MSF Working amid intensifying violence Violence against civilians in Port au Prince is a daily occurrence, and the number of wounded treated by MSF continues to grow.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Honduras-Caring For Street Children
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo © Boyan Stone Caring for street childrenMSF, in cooperation with local organizations, started a program to assist street children and youth in the capital city, Tegucigalpa. Currently, about 30 street children visit the center each day, with approximately 400 extremely poor children between the ages of a few months to 24 years, registered in the program.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: India-Conflict in Assam
properties.description: MSF Country Summary This MSF clinic provides health care for the displaced people of Assam. Photo © Henk Braam Malaria is the main cause of illness in Assam. MSF treats approximately 10,000 malaria patients a month (during the rainy season) using artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT). It has also run mobile clinics to the more than 50 camps housing members of the ethnic groups involved in the clashes.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Indonesia-Tsunami Counseling
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An Indonesian psychologist leads a discussion group of tsunami survivors. Photo © Sebastian Bolesch In the aftermath of disaster and conflict Days after an enormous tsunami battered parts of Indonesia's coast, MSF teams began working in cooperation with national efforts to provide assistance to people in need of medical care, food, clean water, shelter and other basic necessities..   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Iran-Earthquake Recovery
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Helping earthquake survivors and Afghan refugees In collaboration with Iranian authorities, an MSF team worked in the health center in the mountain village of Hotkan, home to more than 100 families. Located near the epicenter, Hotkan was almost completely destroyed by the quake. MSF carried out medical consultations and distributed needed supplies including blankets and hygiene kits. The team aided approximately 3,000 people living in this and other affected villages.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Italy-Refugee Aid
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo © Chris Maluszynski/Moment Italy receives thousands of migrants arriving by boat from Africa each year. Upon arrival, many of these people are weakened and in need of food, water and medical attention. In 2005/2006, MSF provided medical care for over 20,000 recent arrivals and migrant workers and opened new projects to reach more people in need   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Ivory Coast-Aftermath of Conflict
properties.description: MSF Country Summary The MSF-supported hospital in Man, Ivory Coast, near Liberia. Photo © Carl De Keyzer/Magnum Photos Renewed violence deepens crisis The ongoing violence has left many without basic health care or sufficient food. MSF is the only provider of basic primary and secondary health care in many of the areas where its teams work.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Kenya-HIV/AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An MSF doctor examines a child in the town of Busia. Photo © Pep Bonet A dramatic increase in AIDS care The health system suffers from chronic neglect and staff and drug shortages are common, especially in rural areas. As a result, many people die due to a lack of care and treatment. MSF's activities in Kenya are an effort to improve the lives of some of those living with HIV/AIDS. Today, MSF is treating more than 5,600 HIVpositive patients and caring for thousands more.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Lesotho-HIV/AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary MSF physician Prinitha Pillay consults with a 12-year-old boy who was the first patient to receive antiretroviral treatment through MSF's project in Lesotho.  Photo © Wayne Conradie MSF opens new HIV/AIDS program in Lesotho Maseru, Lesotho  In January 2006 MSF launched a new HIV/AIDS program in Lesotho. The program aims to provide free HIV/AIDS care and treatment to as many people as possible in a rural health district south of the capital, Maseru. It also aims to strengthen the capacity of local health workers to reduce HIV-related deaths and improve and extend the lives of people with HIV/AIDS.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Liberia-Primary Care
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo © Jason Cone/MSF Responding to many needs Although Liberia's bloody civil conflict has ended and a transitional government was created in 2003, most Liberians continue to struggle for their very survival. A shortage of health personnel, particularly in rural areas, leaves many people without basic health care. Improving access to primary and secondary health care services is at the heart of MSF's work in Liberia   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Malawi-HIV/AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © MSF/Clara Breitenecker Improving AIDS care In Malawi, most MSF activities are focused on improving care and services for those living with HIV/AIDSa population numbering more than one million adults and children. Although the government has plans to scale up HIV/AIDS services, in reality, 90 percent of public health facilities lack the capacity to offer even the most basic health care.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Mali-Malaria & Cholera Care
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Jean Bourgeois/MSF Improving malaria and cholera care Civilians in Mali face recurring epidemics of cholera, measles and meningitis. Despite these ongoing threats to health, the basic medical needs of the country's 12 million inhabitants remain largely unmet. MSF makes a priority of improving people's access to care and the quality of treatment.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Mauritania-Fighting Cholera
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Jean Bourgeois/MSF Fighting cholera Concerned about a major cholera outbreak in the capital city of Nouakchott, MSF has opened a new emergency project in Mauritania after years of providing basic health care and treatment for malnourished children   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Morocco-Sub-Saharan Immigrants
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Morocco is a transit country for thousands of immigrants and asylum seekers on their way to Europe. © Amanda Sans Caring for sub-Saharan immigrants In the northwestern city of Tangier and the surrounding areas, including Bel Younech forest, MSF works to improve the health and living conditions of this extremely disadvantaged group. An MSF team conducts mobile medical clinics and monitors the immigrant community for epidemiological outbreaks.     Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Mozambique-HIV/AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Francesco Zizola/Magnum Photos In 2001, MSF began work in Maputo city. At the Alto Maé health center and Chamanculo Hospital, MSF has been working to improve the quality of HIV/AIDS services, including voluntary counseling and HIV testing, prevention of mother-to-child transmission of the virus, and care and treatment of opportunistic infections.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Myanmar-HIV/AIDS & Malaria
properties.description: MSF Country Summary MSF uses mobile clinics to visit villages for malaria treatment and prevention. © Olivier Bonnet HIV/AIDS & MalariaHelping the most vulnerable MSF's activities in Myanmar target the most vulnerable groups in the country including those living with malaria, tuberculosis and sexually transmitted infections including HIV/AIDS. Malaria is a concern throughout the country, and MSF has been involved with malaria-treatment programs in Myanmar for nearly a decade.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Nepal-Medical Care in a Ceasefire
properties.description: MSF Country Summary In Nepal, the steep topography and 10 years of conflict limit the populations' access to medical care. Photo © William Martin / MSF Finding a Way to Work Independently in a Fragmented Country Despite a return to calm and the hope of a lasting peace, the Nepalese people still have only limited access to medical care. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has managed to find a way to work independently in isolated mountainous regions that have been divided by the conflict, which has lasted for more than 10 years   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Niger-Malnutrition
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An MSF doctor examines a two year old girl. Photo © Raphael Weber / MSF MSF has been assisting those with severe malnutrition in the Maradi district of Niger since 2001. In 2005, MSF began an emergency operation to treat tens of thousands of children suffering from severe acute malnutrition in various parts of the country.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Nigeria-HIV/AIDS
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Photo MSF HIV/AIDS Most of those in urgent need of life-prolonging treatment for AIDS or related illnesses have no way of getting it, because treatment is unaffordable or unavailable in their area. In Lagos, the countries largest city, MSF is treating more than 1,000 HIV patients with antiretroviral (ARV) medicines at General Hospital Lagos, Lagos Island.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Pakistan-Refugee Care
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © MSF Providing medical aid during tense times Afghanistan's turbulent recent past has had large consequences for neighboring Pakistan and MSF's work there. The murder of five MSF staff in Afghanistan forced the Pakistan-based team to decrease its activities due to security concerns. This occurred at a time when local populations often lack health care and huge numbers of Afghani refugees were trying to survive in border camps despite harsh living conditions and insufficient assitance.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Peru-AIDS Epidemic
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © PH. Merchez A growing AIDS epidemic An estimated 90,000 people are now living with HIV/AIDS in the country. MSF runs a number of projects in poor areas of metropolitan Lima to help control the onset of an HIV/AIDS epidemic in the country. MSF also helps youngsters scarred by violence.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Republic of Congo- Healthcare In A Violent Region
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Benno Neeleman/MSF Today most people living in the Pool area today cannot obtain the most basic health care. In addition, malaria and tuberculosis (TB) outbreaks go relatively unchecked. Because of the dire situation, MSF provides basic health services to people living in the Pool region at three hospitals and nine health posts   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Rwanda-After Genocide
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo © Ian Berry/magnum photos MSF is currently running a number of projects in the country. MSF teams provide care for people living with HIV/AIDS in Kigali, offer reproductive health services in the province of Ruhengeri, provide water and sanitation support in Cyangugu province to fight cholera and run a nationwide project assisting traumatized women.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Sierra Leone-Caring for Survivors
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Robert Knoth In a country where most people survive as farmers and large families are believed to be essential, women are expected to have as many children as possible. Many die in childbirth or on their way to get help, or suffer serious complications; and many babies do not survive infancy. MSF works in the pediatric and maternity wards of the district hospital in Kambia, in northwest Sierra Leone   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: South Africa-AIDS & Rape Survivors
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An MSF doctor examines a child in an HIV/AIDS project in Khayelitsha, South Africa. © Mariella Furrer With more than 6.5 million people living with HIV, South Africa has the largest number of HIV-positive people in the world. MSF is working in low-income areas of the Western Cape and Eastern Cape, providing life-extending antiretroviral (ARV) medicines and related care for HIV-positive patients.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Spain-Aid to Migrants
properties.description: MSF Country Summary An MSF staff member helps an exhausted, cold African refugee who has just arrived in Fuerteventura. © Juan Medina There are more than one million undocumented migrants in Spain, and thousands continue to enter the country each year. The government announced measures in October 2004 to legalize hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants already in the country in an effort to boost the failing economy and incorporate these people into the tax-paying labor market.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Tanzania-HIV/AIDS & Malaria
properties.description: MSF Country Summary Photo © Monica Rull / Victoria Perez In Tanzania, MSF cares for people affected by malaria and HIV/AIDS. The team also assisted vulnerable refugees arriving from Burundi with little or no resources.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Thailand-Assisting Marginalized Groups
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Photo: MSF/Florian Breitenecker Comprehensive care and treatment for people with HIV/AIDS has become a principal activity for MSF in Thailand, where more than one million people are estimated to be HIV-positive. MSF also assists marginalized groups such as refugees, migrant workers, and women and children.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Turkmenistan-Improving Children's Health Care
properties.description: A top 10 underreported humanitarian story of 2006 ©UNICEF/Turkmenistan/Pirozzi MSF is now targeting its work in the economically deprived city of Magdanly, located in the far east of the country. The region is a forgotten one within Turkmenistan and the health care system is in shambles. See why some volunteered for MSF.

properties.name: Uganda-Victims of Violence
properties.description: MSF Country Summary © Harald Henden Providing care for victims of violence and disease In addition to mounting an emergency response to help alleviate some of the suffering in the north, its teams are assisting refugees fleeing violence in the neighboring Democratic Republic of the Congo. MSF also continues to treat people with infectious diseases such as HIV/AIDS, malaria and kala azar in remote parts of the country.   Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Uzbekistan-Drug Resistant TB
properties.description: A top 10 underreported humanitarian story of 2006 © Petter Hveem Treating patients with resistant TB A health survey found that Karakalpakstan's residents have the highest incidence of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) in the entire Aral Sea region. In this desolate area, MSF works closely with the national Ministry of Health in the city of Nukus to treat people living with MDR-TB. Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Zambia-HIV/AIDS
properties.description: A top 10 underreported humanitarian story of 2006 Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) home-based care project for people suffering from Aids. Doctor Ssonko Charles inspects the mouth of a patient during a visit to his home. © Pep Bonet MSF has been working in Zambia since 1999, providing emergency medical care to refugees and displaced people, responding to disease outbreaks and meeting other urgent health needs. Most recently, its activities have focused primarily on preventing the further spread of HIV and improving the lives of those living with AIDS. Why some volunteer for MSF

properties.name: Zimbabwe-Healthcare in Crisis
properties.description: A top 10 underreported humanitarian story of 2006 Harare - Zimbabwe authorities banned Medecins Sans Frontiers (MSF) from assisting displaced families at a holding camp outside Harare. © Zim Online(SA) MSF is working in various parts of this country in crisis to bring urgently needed health care to some of Zimbabwe's most vulnerable populations, including many made homeless by government "cleanup" operations carried out in numerous city slums. Why some volunteer for MSF
